The association between mental health and obesity in postmenopausal women: A systematic review
Mona Mohamed Ibrahim Abdalla 1, Meram Azzani 2, Wahib Atroosh 3, Deepa Anbazhagan 4, Vinoth Kumarasamy 5
1Physiology Department, Human Biology Division, School of Medicine, International Medical University (IMU), Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; 2Department of Public Health Medicine, Faculty of Medicine, Universiti Teknologi MARA, Sungai Buloh, Malaysia; 3Department of Parasitology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Malaya, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia;
4Medical Microbiology Unit, International Medical School (IMS), Management and Science University (MSU), Selangor, Malaysia; 5Department of Pre-Clinical Sciences, Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences, Universiti Tunku Abdul Rah-
man, Kajang, Selangor, Malaysia E-mail: dr_memeazzani@yahoo.com
Postmenopausal women are at great risk of mental health deterioration, which may lead to morbidity and mortality. The decrement of mental health with aging is attributed to hormonal changes, lowered physical activity, sleep disturbances, economic factors, as well as modifiable variables such as smoking and obesity. Studies have shown controversial results on the association between obesity and mental health in postmenopausal women. This study is a systematic review of the evidence available on the association between obesity and mental health in postmenopausal women with the aim to identify the most reliable obesity measure that has been shown in association with mental health as well as the effective measures that have been practiced for improving mental health in postmenopausal obese women. CINAHL, Scopus, Science Direct and PubMed including Medline databases were searched. Out of 3,766 articles, 23 studies of average to good quality were included, out of which 17 were cross-sectional and 6 interventional. Out of the 17 studies, 12 showed a positive association between obesity and deterioration of mental health, 3 showed a negative association and two showed no association. From the interventional studies, 4 showed positive and two not significant impact of the intervention used on obesity and mental health. In conclusion, more studies showed a positive association between obesity, especially visceral obesity, and mental health issues particularly depression, anxiety, and sleep disorders. Combination of caloric restriction and exercise seems to have a better impact on the mental health of the postmenopausal in comparison with other interventions.
Key words: postmenopausal women, obesity, mental health, depression, anxiety

Women in their postmenopausal stage experience various menopausal symptoms, which may have a range of severity. These factors, which contribute to the severity may vary in relation to hormonal status, association with other diseases, treatment procedures underwent, familial characteristics, and socio-demographic factors. This transition that takes
place in women due to aging may be related to a lot of metabolic changes, obesity, mental health, and other disease conditions (Chedraui and Perez-Lopez 2013).
There are studies reporting that excessive body weight that is experienced in females in their middle age might increase the incidence of vasomotor symptoms and other diseased

conditions (Chedraui et al. 2014). Obesity could be an important component of the metabolic syndrome (METS) and directly related to other inflammatory reactions, which could increase the risk of severe life-threatening conditions (Fernandez-Alonso et al. 2010). METS has been defined to include lipid and non-lipid factors that could increase the cardiovascular risk (Fernandez-Alonso et al. 2010). There are a lot of evidences indicating that METS, of which the obesity is a dominant component, could possibly contribute to most of the postmenopausal symptoms (Lee et al. 2012). This study has concluded that obesity, as an independent factor, has been related to increased severity of menopausal symptoms. Obesity and severe menopausal symptoms have been related to increased cardiovascular risks, education and counselling should be promoted among the high-risk group of people (Fernandez-Alonso et al. 2010). This must include lifestyle habits change, weight loss program, and family education concerning the menopausal transition. The menopausal status associated with the risk that METS carries is independent of the normal aging process (Lobo 2008). There are studies indicating that an increase in the body fat and abdominal obesity among postmenopausal women might have an association with the hormonal changes that occur at that phase (Lizcano and Guzman 2014). It has also been shown that increased central obesity is associated with increased hot flushes, which is a predominant menopausal issue (Thurston et al. 2008). There are several studies reporting the relationship between METS and psychological symptoms of depression and anxiety, urogenital symptoms, and sexual dysfunction (Esposito and Giugliano 2005; Laudisio et al. 2009).
Another important component of the METS is the mental health. However, many factors are involved in determining the severity of the postmenopausal syndrome. Physical and mental health impairments have been reported in many postmenopausal women. Postmenopausal women are more likely to experience symptoms, which are closely related to the changes in their hormonal levels during this phase of their life (Carr 2003; Grundy et al. 2004). In women, lowered estrogen levels during the postmenopausal stage have been linked to depression, reduced libido, and cognitive disorders (Schmidt et al. 2015). There are evidences indicating that obesity and mental depressive states, along with other contributing factors, may play an important role in increasing the frequency and severity of the postmenopausal symptoms.
The ways, by which obesity may affect postmenopausal women’s quality of life have also been identified (Jones and Sutton 2008). The menopausal transition on mood including depression, anxiety, and other psychological symptoms has been reviewed (Vesco et al. 2007). The bidirectional relationship between obesity and mental health disorders in adult men and women has been demonstrated (Mannan et al. 2016). There were few other systematic reviews on the interventional studies done in these disorders. However, we did not find any systematic reviews on the association between mental health and obesity in postmenopausal women.
In this context, the primary objectives of this systematic review were to: 1) investigate the association between the mental health and the obesity among postmenopausal women, 2) identify the common types of mental health disorders related to the postmenopausal obesity, 3) identify the obesity measures that are most likely to be associated with the mental health disorders in postmenopausal women, and 4) identify and investigate the effectiveness of the different interventional methods used in combating the postmenopausal obesity-related mental health disorders as a secondary objective.

sections.heading: Methodology
sections.text:
In conducting this systematic review, the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Review and MetaAnalysis (PRISMA) guidelines were followed (Moher et al. 2009). In regard to eligibility criteria, original articles that reported the obesity and its effect on the mental health status and/or quality of the postmenopausal women’s life published before 16 May 2019, were included. There was no limit placed on the language, publication year or study setting. Papers that did not report obesity, systematic review papers, technical reports, conference proceedings, papers on specific health disorders, and those that measured the outcome among the general population, were excluded from this review.
Search strategy. CINAHL, Scopus, Science Direct, and PubMed including Medline databases were searched. The keywords utilized were: mental health, quality of life, obesity, post-menopause and their synonyms, and MESH terms. Hand searching of the bibliography of included publications was utilized so that studies that might not be found during the online search could be identified.
Study identification. Totally, 3,766 articles were identified during the initial screening (Figure 1). First off, a search strategy was developed by two authors.

The keywords and their synonyms were identified. All studies from different databases were transferred into the Endnote X7 software, whereas 42 duplicate papers were removed. The remaining 3,724 articles were reviewed based on their titles and abstracts by two authors independently. In the case of disagreement between the two reviewers, the final classification was made by a consensus with the contribution of the third reviewer. Consequently, 104 articles were totally selected for the assessment of the full text. Two other authors evaluated the eligibility of the retained papers. The bibliography of the selected articles was checked for any relevant articles, which met the inclusion criteria of this systematic review and were not retrieved during the searches. As a result, one study was included. After a full review of 104 papers, 17 were selected for this review. Data extraction was finalized and all authors agreed on the eligibility of retained papers.
Quality assessment. For quantitative studies, a quality assessment of cross-sectional studies (BSA medical sociology group) was used (Blaxter 1996), which composed of seven questions. Each question responded with either a yes (1 point) or no (0 point). A score of 1–2 was considered of low, 3–5 medium, and 6–7 high quality. For interventional studies, the Oxford quality scoring system; Jadad Scale (Janad and Enkin 2007), was used, which is scored from 0 to 5. Papers with less than 3 points were considered of low and papers of 3 or more points were considered high quality. The quality assessment of included studies is illustrated in data extraction Table 1.
Data extraction. The data extracted included author, year of publication, study setting, sampling and methodology, main results, study limitation, and conclusion (Table 1).

This systematic review includes 23 papers, 17 cross-sectional and 6 interventional studies. The sample size of included studies varied between 40 to 8,745 subjects with the age between 35–86 years.
Relation of psycho-social domains to obesity
Previous studies have shown that obese and overweight women had significantly higher scores in psycho-social domains. The findings showed that menopause-related psycho-social symptoms had negative impact on their quality of life (Chedraui et al. 2007; Mirhaghjou et al. 2016). In a study conducted in postmenopausal women in Ecuadorian
population, abdominal obesity increased the risk of having vasomotor, psycho-social, and physical scores above the median. Hypertension and hyperglycemia increased the risk for higher scores within the psycho-social and sexual domains, respectively. The impairment of life quality was found to be associated with age and other related conditions such as abdominal obesity, hypertension, and hyperglycemia (Chedraui et al. 2007). Besides, both psychic and somatic symptoms were significantly related to the body-shape characteristics. Nervousness, mood changes, sleeplessness, and libido loss were more commonly observed in postmenopausal women with increasing breadth and circumference and/or increasing body weight (Kirchengast 1993).
Depressive symptoms associated with obesity
In a study carried out among 117 Chinese postmenopausal women who had depressive symptoms, 44 participants had abdominal obesity. Besides, increasing anger over time was longitudinally associated with an increasing waist circumference (Raikkonen et al. 1999). The body fat percentage, waist/hip ratio, and leptinemia were positively correlated with anxiety and depression scores in postmenopausal women. In all the overweight midlife women, these symptoms were more strongly associated with age and leptin levels than reproductive aging itself. The data indicate that in overweight middle-aged women with abdominal obesity, the aging process and the development of leptin resistance are associated with impairment of mental health (Naufel et al. 2018, 2019). The mental exhaustion and depressive mood were highly prevalent in postmenopausal sample, whereby the severity of menopausal symptoms correlated with abdominal obesity (Fernandez-Alonso et al. 2010; Chedraui et al. 2013). Besides, higher body mass index (BMI) in postmenopausal women with smaller waist-hip-ratio was associated with poorer cognitive function. Higher waist-hip-ratio estimating central fat mass was associated with higher cognitive function (Kerwin et al. 2010). On the other hand, insomnia in overweight postmenopausal women also plays a crucial role in the impairment of the mental health (Chedraui et al. 2013).
Negative association/no relationship between BMI and psychological well-being
A few previous studies have shown a negative association between BMI and the psychological well-being. BMI was positively related to the habitual susceptibility to disinhibition in 131 postmenopausal women. Women with a higher score of habitual susceptibility to disinhibition had a lower level of psychological well-being compared to those having a lower score of habitual susceptibility to disinhibition, regardless of their weight status (Provencher et al. 2007). In another study, 30% of the sample have reported mild to major depressive symptoms and 70% fewer depressive symptoms. Pearson correlation showed an insignificant correlation between BMI with mental health in postmenopausal women (Seib et al. 2013). Another study highlighted a decline in the cognitive functions in postmenopausal women with normal BMI as compared to overweight ones. Overweight postmenopausal women exhibited less decline in cognitive visuospatial ability and episodic memory than normal-weight women (Thilers et al. 2010). Similarly, no relationship between BMI and psychological symptoms of depression nor anxiety in postmenopausal women has also been reported (Mirzaiinjmabadi et al. 2006).
306 Mental health and obesity in postmenopausal women
Treatment and prevention of depressive symptoms associated with obesity
Various treatment and prevention method have been used to combat depressive symptoms associated with obesity. The combined administration of fluoxetine and melatonin was used as a useful option to treat mood, sleep, and appetite disorders in overweight postmenopausal women. A statistically significant reduction at anxiety and depression levels was observed after 24 weeks. This reduction was observed in women with unchanged BMI and also reduced BMI (Chojnacki et al. 2015). Exercise, which resulted in a weight loss also brought an improvement in the mental and physical health, but the results were not significant (Van Gemert et al. 2015). However, a significant reduction in perceived stress and depression via proper diet and exercise has been reported (Lemoine et al. 2007; De Tapsoba et al. 2016). These findings indicate that the combination of dietary weight loss and exercise may have a larger beneficial effect on HRQOL compared with dietary weight loss or exercise itself (De Tapsoba et al. 2016). Besides, exercise combined with phytoestrogens improves the quality of life in the postmenopausal women rather than the exercise alone (Riesco et al. 2011).
Indirect association between depressive symptoms and weight
In a few studies, the presence of indirect association between depressive symptoms and weight has been shown. Stress eating has been shown to be a significant mediator between depressive symptoms and weight significantly associated in postmenopausal women (Schreiber and Dautovich 2017). Besides, the level of education in postmenopausal women has also been reported to have a significant role in depressive symptoms. For postmenopausal women with lower education, a higher BMI is associated with lower score of depressive symptoms (Jasienska et al. 2005). It was also reported that weight loss correlated with a small to moderate improvement in perceived general health and energy. However, it was reversed by weight gain in postmenopausal women (Yankura et al. 2008).

sections.heading: Discussion
sections.text:
The escalating prevalence of obesity represents a global burden affecting different age groups including postmenopausal women (Flegal et al.
2010; Teede et al. 2010; Xi et al. 2012; Bagnoli et al. 2014; da Costa Pimenta et al. 2020). Studies have reported an association of many co-morbidities with obesity such as insulin resistance (Kahn and Flier 2000), malignancy (Berger 2014), and mental health disorders including insomnia, depression, anxiety, etc. (Van Vuuren et al. 2019). Anxiety and depression have also found to be common in postmenopausal women due to hormonal changes during menopause, lifestyle changes, social factors, ethnicity, and body image (Kim et al. 2018; Simbar et al. 2020). Controversial findings have been reported regarding the association between obesity and mental health deterioration in postmenopausal women, where positive or negative association (Kirchengast 1993; Provencher et al. 2007; Fernandez-Alonso et al. 2010) as well as negative or no association (Mirzaiinjmabadi et al. 2006; Kerwin et al. 2010; Thilers et al. 2010; Seib et al. 2013) have been reported in some studies.
This systematic review aimed to: 1) review the pieces of evidence available on the type of association between obesity and mental health in postmenopausal women, 2) identify, which from the obesity measures is most likely be associated with the mental health, and 3) review the evidence available on the effectiveness of various interventional methods used to combat obesity-and its related mental health disorders in postmenopausal women. From 17 crosssectional studies relevant to this topic, 12 studies have been reported in positive association with obesity and mental health deterioration in postmenopausal women, especially depression, anxiety, and sleep disorders (Kirchengast 1993; Raikkonen et al. 1999; Katz et al. 2000; Chedraui et al. 2007, 2014; Provencher et al. 2007; Fernandez-Alonso et al. 2010; Mirhaghjou et al. 2016; Xiong et al. 2017; Naufel et al. 2018; 2019). Body mass index (BMI), visceral fat (VF), waist circumference (WC), waist-to-hip ratio (WHR) were used as measures of obesity. From the anthropometric measures, VF (visceral fat) and WC; the best predictor for VF (Raikkonen et al. 1999) showed a negative impact on the psychological well-being of the postmenopausal women (Kerwin et al. 2010; Xiong et al. 2017). Decreased estrogen level during menopause, the lack of physical activity, and consumption of unhealthy food contribute to the accumulation of the abdominal fat (Vanis et al. 2018), which subsequently negatively impact the women’s perception of their body image (Simbar et al. 2020).
An excessive accumulation of body fat, especially the abdominal one has also been hypothesized to
307Abdalla, et al.
be involved in development and progression of depression (Baudrand and Vaidya 2015) via the activated hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis (Pasquali et al. 2008), which has been found to be overactivated in 75% of patients with major depression. HPA overactivation may result from glucocorticoids hypersecretion and a subsequent higher accumulation of the visceral fat (Valtonen et al. 2012), where adipocytes are rich in glucocorticoid receptors (Pasquali et al. 2008). In addition, visceral obesity plays a crucial role in the development of insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes mellitus, which are likely to contribute to mood disorders via the alteration of cerebral vessels and brain metabolites (Ajilore et al. 2007). Increased resistance to leptin in obese individuals may also contribute to the increased incidence of depressive mood and anxiety due to the potential protective role of leptin as an antidepressant (Lu et al. 2006; Lu 2007). In addition to these biological mechanisms, the perceptions of postmenopausal women regarding overweight and obesity may cause psychological distress, dissatisfaction with body image, loss of self-esteem, loss of attractiveness, and sexual dysfunction (Thomas et al. 2019), which may impact their mental health (Atlantis and Ball 2008). These evidences emphasize the importance of mental health monitoring when treating obesity and the need to control the weight gain when treating mood and anxiety disorders, especially in aging females.
On the other hand, a negative association between BMI and depression has been reported by Jasienska et al. (2005) in postmenopausal women with lower but not higher education level, reinforcing the role of education level as a contributor to the depression (Ahlawat et al. 2019). This negative association can be explained by the possibility of depression causing eating disorders that resulted in low BMI. Another study conducted in Stockholm has reported that the cognitive functions of postmenopausal women with normal BMI are more likely to decline faster than overweight postmenopausal women (Thilers et al. 2010). They have suggested that the higher level of estrogen in overweight postmenopausal women may have a protective effect on the cognitive performance. The main source of estrogen in postmenopause is it being produced in adipose tissue resulting in higher levels of both estradiol and estrone in overweight women (Rannevik et al. 2008). This was supported by a reliable positive association between BMI and estradiol level in their study (Thilers et al. 2010). This is also evidenced by the better effect of combining phytoestrogen with
mixed exercise than exercise alone in improving the mental health and quality of life in postmenopausal women (Riesco et al. 2011). The third study has reported that higher BMI was associated with poorer cognitive function in women with smaller WHR. Higher WHR, estimating central fat mass, was associated with higher cognitive function in this cross-sectional study (Kerwin et al. 2010), which was also associated with higher estrogen level enforcing the importance of identifying the cut-off point of the serum estrogen level that can protect the postmenopausal women from the deterioration in her cognitive function. An absence of association between mental health and obesity has been reported in two studies conducted in postmenopausal women in Queensland (Mirzaiinjmabadi et al. 2006; Seib et al. 2013). This can be due to a higher level of estrogen secretion in obese postmenopausal women as compared to the lean postmenopausal ones, and the possibility of an indirect relation between BMI and mental health by affecting the sleep of the participants. The association between obesity and the mental health of postmenopausal women has been also evidenced by the effectiveness of weight reduction interventions, such as diet, exercise or combination of both in improving the mental health-related quality of life as well as reducing the severity of menopausal symptoms as it has been shown in the data extracted (Lemoine et al. 2007; Imayama et al. 2011; Van Gemert et al. 2015). Combined administration of fluoxetine and melatonin has been reported as a useful option in treating mood, sleep, and appetite disorders in overweight postmenopausal women (Chojnacki et al. 2015).
Conclusion
Many studies have reported a negative impact of obesity, particularly visceral obesity, on the mental health of postmenopausal women through the link with depression, anxiety, and sleep disorders. The best obesity measure that can predict a mental health decline in postmenopausal women is the visceral fat and/or waist circumference. The combination of increased physical activity with caloric restriction seems to be the most effective intervention to improve the mental health and the quality of life in postmenopausal women.
